content: #15522 is from a new contributor and has been sitting for three weeks now; @Eric Wieser has already commented earlier and that suggestion was addressed. Maybe @Violeta Hernández is interested?

Sorry, this is a topic I had never heard of before. To be clear, the "ordinal approximants" for a function f at x are the values f^α(x) defined by f^0(x) = x and f^α(x) = sup {f(f^β(x)) | β < α}, right?

I don't like the name "ordinal approximants", it suggests the ordinals are the ones doing the approximation, when really it's the function values. But if that's the standard name in the literature then I'm not complaining I'll redirect my complaints elsewhere
I appreciate the links to references, but I still wish the docstrings explained the file better
As for the actual PR, I'll try and review it shortly.
I saw "ordinal" and couldn't help thinking of you :sweat_smile:

I am a bit worried for how useful this file might potentially be. Both of the linked papers focus exclusively on showing that the fixed points of a complete lattice are a complete lattice, but we already have this result in Mathlib! It's docs#fixedPoints.completeLattice
The benefit of "having a constructive proof" is also a non-starter. Mathlib freely assumes choice almost everywhere, and really, our treatment of ordinals is hopelessly nonconstructive anyways.
